[h1]Quick Info[/h1]

[i]Vaporum[/i] is a standard dungeon crawler along the lines of [i]Legend of Grimrock[/i]. It’s combat is well polished while the puzzles tend to be simpler and more active then they are mental. The general polish of the game seems to come from the fact that Vaporum does not bring any serious innovation to the genre. That being said, the change in setting from the normal fantasy to steampunk was nice, if not a bit superficial in regards to gameplay. There is more story to [i]Vaporum[/i] than other games of this genre, but that element remains as flavor for the gameplay rather than a robust part of the game. If you have a hankering for more dungeon crawling, than Vaporum will be your cup of tea. It faithfully follows in the footsteps of [i]Grimrock[/i].

39373725.review:
This game is a very good example of clear and straight game design. They implemented all things based on a clear Dungeon Master formula.
The riddles are all fair but sometimes hard and tricky.
I played it through and can recommend it for all liking old school game design, which stands here for a good thing.

The story is hooked around a good plot and the setting is close to some other games but gets standalone after a while in its own setting. 

The one top feature for me, one I cannot praise enough, is the time stop function, which lets you step through the game in slow motion. 
This makes the fights go from realtime to tactical. Ok, they are not too hard this way but its fun to think an react. 
Otherwise it would kill the entire game, making it unplayable in a few but enough situations, at least for me.

Nonetheless there are some not so good implementations:

- The 'R' key is used for Repair, which consumes a repair kit immediately. But it is located directly near the Turn-Right key 'E', which is very unlucky.

- When solving puzzles in an area, where a lot of pits and contact plates are placed, you die very commonly by pressing a 
wrong direction key.  Nobody would do this at will and this leads to a very concentrated playing in places where no stress is needed.

- Placing Gadgets into the fast access row leads sometimes to accidently unleashing them, when you wanted just to replace a gadget, which is best done in inventory, but works also this way.

O Vaporum się dowiedziałem z forum gry-online. Początkowo byłem dosyć niechętnie nastawiony na tą grę, ale trafiłem na dobrą okazję na bazarze łowców gier i postanowiłem grę zakupić. I była to bardzo dobra decyzja.

Gra należy do gatunku Dungeon Crawlerów w klimacie steampunka. Poruszamy się w grze po polach (tak jak to jest m.in. w Might and magic X czy Legend of grimrock), ale akcja się dzieje w czasie rzeczywistym. Plansze po których się poruszamy są dosyć klaustrofobiczne, ale ładne i klimatyczne. Walka w grze jest czymś pomiędzy Bioshockiem (mamy broń białą, palną i gadżety) i Legend of Grimrock. Rozwój postaci jest prosty, ale schludny i nie ma co się rozwodzić, bo gra jest bardziej nastawiona na akcję niż taktykę, co moim zdaniem nie jest wadą. 
Fabuła jest okryta mgłą tajemnicy, którą po kawałeczku odkrywamy odczytując notatki i odsłuchując audiologi, a czasem z monologu głównego bohatera. 

Warto też odszukiwać sekretów, bo tam są ukryte unikatowy sprzęt oraz wzmacniacze sprzętu. Niestety same sekrety mogłyby być jakoś ciekawiej poukrywane. Większość z nich jest oparta o przekręcenie jakieś śruby na któreś ze ścian... Przy tak słabo oświetlonych lokacjach jest to bardzo żmudne zajęcie. 

Zagadki natomiast są proste, ale mało irytujące. Nie ma w nich niczego co nie było już w innych grach, ale zdecydowanie przyjemnie się je rozwiązuje. Czasem potrafią postawić wyzwanie. :)

Ogólnie grę polecam miłośnikom Dungeon Crawlerów oraz ludziom, którzy dopiero chcą się zabrać za ten gatunek. Gra potrafi postawić wyzwanie (polecam oszczędzać zestawy naprawcze).

39115847.review:
[h1]=== Intro ===[/h1]
Actually, I'd recommend the game to anyone liking the genre and who can forgive its smaller and bigger discrepancies (see below).
However, at time of this review, there's no decent negative review explaining all its shortcomings.
Plus, the game enjoys showing both its fingers to the player (see "Secrets" section below). So that's my answer. 0:-)

[h1]=== My Opinion ===[/h1]
Vaporum is a very decent grid based dungeon crawler that every fans of the genre should try, especially Legend of Grimrock 2 fans. However, there's almost nothing great in it ; most parts are good, and some are so so or worst.

It took me 14 hours to complete.

[h1]=== Combat ===[/h1]
Combat is a very important part of the game and it's what LoG2 combat should have been : it's usually challenging, from a bit to very much, depending of the enemies, without being too painful nor too boring.

It's not without flaws, though: I played in Hard difficulty (4th one out of 5), and during the 1st levels, every time I was hit I wanted to quick load to avoid wasting the few repair kits available through the game. After that, we get a gadget that lets suck life out of our enemies, which greatly encourages us to stall each fight for a long time to get all our health back before it ends, and it gets pretty boring quickly.

Game is also plagued of "I enter an empty room, all doors close, then a bunch of enemies spawn" ; there's the variant with "enemies spawn in my back so I can't run away". It happens way more often than it should.

So there's a lot of multi-enemy fights, which is good for me as it requires better reflexes and adaptive skills than basic square dancing. And often even with only 1 enemy, it's still very entertaining, as most of them have area-of-effect attack, or ranged attack, or jump, or other surprises. So the few ones without a trick are actually welcome as they offer a break from the hard ones.

But as all square-dancing combat system, this one is still hindered by the lack of damage when we play perfectly. And thus it gets too easy, and boring. Which meant I lost focus countless of times as the game failed to keep my attention (and I got smashed in the face in return :-p ).

However, to play perfectly, you'll need to have top notch reflexes, as most enemies give you no margin for error. So if your reflexes are average, difficulty will ramp up pretty quickly, especially in multi-enemy fights where it might become a nightmare.

Controls are a bit sluggish, especially when strafing : you get a quarter-of-second pause each time you reach a new cell, and it kinda kills the flow. I got used to it after a few hours, but never liked it.

Final boss fight is ok, special enough, but not great. Saving is disabled during it, but you get frequent autosaves instead, so it's alright.

[h1]=== Character Build ===[/h1]
At start of the game, you get to choose amongst 4 rigs, each giving bonuses in specific areas of the combat. Changes are relatively small if don't play in Hard or Brutal difficulties, so they don't command to do a 2nd run to enjoy a new experience.

Each time you level up, you get a point to put in a talent tree. Choices are relatively basic, and bare a few exceptions they don't modify the gameplay much. Once again, it's ok but not great.

[h1]=== Exploration/Story ===[/h1]
Exploration is pretty decent: level design is not great but it's usually good all along.

Main issue is that almost everything look the same: mostly dark with tubes and giant gears everywhere, and small lights all around. When checking the user screenshots in Steam, I can't guess from what level they are for at least 80% of them ; worst, I even don't know if they are from the beginning, the middle or the end of the game, as it just looks same for the whole ride, with a few exceptions.

I just finished the game, and in my still fresh memory, the whole thing is just a blur with barely any special notes.

Story and story telling are pretty bland ; it feels like what an AI would write after have read all stories from the scifi games of the past 15 years: there's not a single original nor fresh element. Plus ending is a bad joke.

World doesn't make much sense: who would want to have a deadly trap next to his office?

So almost the whole level layout is a maze-hell and doesn't look like anything functional. In itself, it's not really penalizing in the genre. But the story being "normal" (think Bioshock story), it constantly creates a distortion about what we read in notes & hear in audio-logs and what we see in the actual world.

[h1]=== Puzzles ===[/h1]
Puzzles are globally ok but not great, with some being particularly obtuse or some others just plain badly designed: one of the puzzle requires you to look in the correct direction several times in a row to see where you have to go next. If you don't guess where to look correctly, you die. Another one requires brute force to be solved, while having 20 possible solutions and a good possibility to mess many attempts if you don't have a good location memory.

And some of the worst puzzles are mandatory to finish the game.

Also, there are a bunch of timed puzzles requiring a perfect timing to be solved. There's a kind of stop-time mode that may help you if you have bad reflexes, though.

[h1]=== Secrets ===[/h1]
It's pretty rare for a game to need a special section to describe its secrets, but this game does.

So there are only few secrets, just a bit more than 2 per levels. But the big, huge, awful issue is that past the easy secrets of the 1st couple levels, you'll have to notice misplaced screws to find most of the secrets!

Let's show you an example : http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1257549787
If you can't notice the secret button, it's the [spoiler]screw under the red light on the right[/spoiler]. And this one is in the top 30% of the easiest secrets.

For another secret, the screw is hidden at 90% by a beam.

There are thousands if not tens of thousands of screws in the game. You can't see them from far, you can't see them well from close either because your suit light either dazzles in the center or doesn't light enough on the edges.

Oh, it doesn't stop there either! A good bunch of these screws are placed in middle of timed traps! What kind of sick idea is that? So not only the screws are hard to spot, but there you have less than half a second to find them and click them.

So at this point you might be thinking: ok, the secret buttons are hard to find, because the secret emplacements are more or less obvious. Wrong! For the most part, secrets can be anywhere, and there's no hint to their location, and when there's some hint, the "wrong" screw can be a dozen of cells away, that's already hundred of screws to check!

And that's not all: not only the secrets contain most of the best gear, they also contain some story elements! So just ignoring them means missing some significant parts of the game!

For me, it feels like the game shows me 2 giant fingers and thus well deserves my negative vote, as a fair gesture back... ;-)


[h1]+ Pros +[/h1]
- Combat is globally nicely challenging and well done
- Decent bestiary, with decent variations and a lot of surprises
- Exploration is nice
- Atmosphere is well done
- Quick Save/Load are super fast and it's super needed! ;-)
- Menu options have tooltips where needed, with plenty to configure to our liking

[h1]- Cons -[/h1]
- Most secrets are awfully painful to find
- Some puzzles are obscure or badly designed
- Story and story telling are bland, while they made it an important part of the game
- Both too dark and too blazing
- Environments are way too similar for the whole game
- No replayability
- Framerate seems a bit low when some of the postprocessing effects are on (they seem to be more costly than in other games)
- Can't see whole map, as it's not fullscreen, which forces you to scroll all around and makes it unnecessarily hard to figure out where to go next

I don't even remember how I heard about Vaporum. Which is a shame because this game is an absolute gem in the Grimrock/Eye/Dungeon Master style dungeon crawler games. But it would be more accurate to say that it is an amazing combination of Bioshock and Grimrock.

The setting is dieselpunk: full of thick shadows, massive grinding gears, and pumps moving some kind of strange substance called Fumium. The tone of the game is dark and serious, with just a hint of madness and more than two helpings of horror. Nothing summarizes this game better than the very first chapter titled "Into The Monster."

[B]Video 10/10:[/B] The graphics are crisp and vivid, with beautiful shafts of light filtering down from overhead tunnels full of pipes, barely illuminating your surroundings and hiding whatever creatures lurk within the dark corners of this dungeon. Each monster have been lovingly crafted, and you can even get an up close and non-lethal look at them in a handy encyclopedia. The only flaw is that the game is perhaps too dark and often does not show off the beautiful art as well as it should.

[B]Sound 7.5/10:[/B] The musical tracks are somewhat short and looping, but do a good job setting the mood for each level. A few times I found myself grinning when the music shifted into a horror theme (Haunting) or heart pounding ominousness (Fumium Experiment). The rest of the time the music was decent enough that I never felt the desire to turn it off and listen to something else -- it was primarily the short and repetitive nature that held the music back from being 8+.

[B]Enemies 8/10:[/B] Square Dancing should be familiar to fans of Grimrock/Eye/Dungeon Master, and you will find plenty of that here. But the monsters do a decent job of being pretty quick, having sidesteps, and attack patterns that are not hard to memorize but become dangerous chaos the moment you add 2+ enemies into the battle. Old fan of dungeon crawlers here, still holding Dungeon Master as an all-time favorite and used to games like Eye of the Beholder, Lands of Lore, Black Crypt, Captive and more recently the two Grimrock. I hesitated a long time for Vaporum: recommend or not? And despite my recommendation, I'm still on the fence. Here is why: on one hand, the production is surprisingly solid and at times impressive. On the other hand, the game falls in the traps that the best titles in the genre managed to avoid. And it repeats its errors, again and again... until you feel like playing something else entirely. 

My first big complain would be that the game insists really heavily on putting you in a small closed room and overwhelming you with enemies. Getting stuck between 3+ enemies, while some of them have a very large AoD means you are bound to sustain a lot of damage and reload often. It's good a couple of times, but repeat this too often and it's just a drag. You see, dungeon crawlers are usually all about thinking and avoiding this kind of situation. Here it is mandatory, to some extent like in the last Doom game. But it's a dungeon crawler, not a fast-paced FPS. 
My second big complain is about the game's mechanics. While some enemies are organic and others mechanical, you will have to adapt your weapon to the enemy in front of you. And you also have firearms for long distance engagements. So far, so good. However, you only have two quick weapon setups to switch between. Which means you will have to manually go in your inventory and change weapons very often. In games like Captive it is not an issue because you control 4 robots and can have melee characters and shooting (or spell-casting in other games) heroes with other specializations. Here, you only have one guy who has to multitask constantly in combat. Or just give up entirely on shooting, because a firearm-only character will lead you nowhere here (see issue #1).

If you can put up with such frustrating issues, Vaporum has a lot to offer. It is best defined as a Grimrock 1 in a Bioshock-ish setting. It is moody, darkly beautiful and especially dangerous. So much so that the difficulty (already from level 2-3) is closer to Chaos Strikes Back than its predecessor Dungeon Master. The puzzles are challenging, especially the timed ones, but they remain good overall. It is nowhere as good as a Grimrock 2 but if you like the genre you should give the game a try, and refund it if it frustrates you more than it should.

[h1] Паровая романтика [/h1] 
   [b]Vaporum[/b] – это таинственный стимпанковый комплекс. Это Биошок в подземелье из Гримрока. Это фантастическая концепция, которая в итоге так и не смогла полноценно раскрыться. 
   Игра без всяких преуменьшений атмосферна – дух сеттинга можно вкусить за счет одной графической составляющей, а не только через аудиодневники и записки (которых тут, впрочем, тоже немало). Чувство постоянной опасности и азарт исследования сопровождают каждый переход в новую комнату. Охота на секретный лут и прокачка костюма – и вовсе безотказные стимуляторы.
   Но первый восторг от эстетики и всех этих светящихся и щелкающих техноштуковин пройдет. И вот вопрос, хватит ли вам внешнего блеска и самых базовых механик. 
   Или в глубине души вы надеялись на большее.

[h1] Гоп-стоп сокобан [/h1] 
   Потому что порой складывается ощущение, что Vaporum зиждется всего на двух столпах: загадках с толканием ящиков и скриптованных засадах. Поиск ключа к очередной запертой двери, уровень с сокобаном, внезапная атака из-за спины и с флангов – вот формула, которая повторяется из раза в раз, по нескольку заходов на уровень. Иногда сокобан заменяется телепортами, а враги атакуют не из-за спины, а прямо с фронта, из-за распахивающихся дверей. Иногда приходится сражаться в узких коридорах, а иногда дают потанцевать на целой арене 4х4 клетки (поверьте, это невероятно щедро). Но и... все?
   Прокачку легко запороть навсегда, особенно на высших уровнях сложности. В паззлах можно загнать себя в крайне нехорошую ситуацию, которую не распутаешь волшебной кнопкой "reset" (потому что ее нет, лучше сразу перезагрузиться). И ценой очередного "сюрприза" может стать последняя аптечка.
   Ошибаться – дорого. Получать внезапный пинок в живот просто потому, что геймдизайнеру захотелось добавить огонька, – еще и обидно. Нехорошее свойство игры полагаться на элемент сюрприза, что в ловушках, что в спавне врагов, можно без проблем законтрить сейв-скаммингом, но зачем? Зачем?

[h1] Эстетический коллапс [/h1] 
   Возвращаясь к вопросу атмосферы и погружения – ну, это одна из очевидных продающих точек игры, почему бы и не поговорить подробнее. Графика крайне приятная, движение и сопутствующие ему анимации плавные, звуковой дизайн прекрасен, арт-дизайн создает целостный образ не только самого комплекса, но и всего сеттинга. Да, первое время игра старается менять декорации каждые один-два этажа, но потом идет на хитрость и начинает комбинировать и подмешивать элементы с разных зон, но это ничего.
   Куда более обидно то, что с таким багажом она не выдает никаких по-настоящему интересных задач.    Ну как же так.
   Vaporum – все еще пристойный кроулер и несомненно услада для глаз, но он мог бы быть чем-то гораздо большим. Не ждите многого, и не будете разочарованы.

38139920.review:
You know, there was a time when "dungeon crawl" felt like something bad and boring for me. Probably more due to disposable boring dungeon quests in RPGs, bad Diablo clones and grindy Japanese action RPGs. I actually didn't play a lot of classic dungeon crawlers, like Ultima Underworld or even newer titles influenced by it like Arx Fatalis and didn't get to understand the good bits of this subgenre of action RPGs until Legend of Grimrock 5 years ago. But since Grimrock, I was highly interested. And there haven't been that many good follow ups to that game, apart from its fantastic sequel. Games usually focus too much on combat, or too much on puzzles, or too much on something else, never really feeling as balanced and as engrossing as Legend of Grimrock games were. Vaporum is one of the better examples so far.

Game does some things differently on a very basic level. It ditches a lot of mechanics and ideas to boil everything down to the core ideas. So you have just one character to control, "magic" is just a set of abilities tied to keys/icons, you don't rest/eat and there are no save crystals, the dungeon is mostly one layer only and secrets and puzzles are usually not that obscure. But at the same time, it attempts to keep all the beauty of exploration, the thrills of encountering enemies and "dancing" around them, the simple joys of skills and leveling up. And it does it surprisingly well.

There are occasional hiccups, which probably will vary depending on how you level up the character (remember to specialize, not spread across everything), but overall game progression in terms of combat and exploration is pretty well paced with just enough challenge to actually feel how powerful you can become by the end, just enough puzzles and secrets to feel smart about figuring them out and just enough variety in levels, that you will probably not get bored. The start can be pretty slow and I feel like some things should've been introduced and spiced up earlier then they do in the game, but when things get going, they never really stop.

Where the game does disappoint is in how... plain and derivative it feels in the rest of things. The plot and story are very heavy influenced by BioShock games, but, more importantly, are just boring and rather badly acted, never even trying to be creative or strange, something that both Grimrock games did really well. The music is "fine". Visually and technologically, the game feels a bit cheap and poorly optimized, a bit too close to the "stock Unity experience" than the style and the setting deserved to have. I mean, there are really beautifully set up scenes and locations, they just could look so much better (and run so much smoother).

But overall, Vaporum is good doze of dungeon crawling that will keep you wanting to play more of it, to explore just one more room, clear out just one more floor. It could've been much better, as Grimrock games show perfectly, but it is still worth a play and I hope the developers get to evolve their craft with whatever next projects they might have.

[list][*]Dungeon crawling is fun!
[*]Nice enemy variety!
[*]Difficulty is mostly fine, with hiccups.

[*]Definitely replayable! Especially for secrets.
[*]Three unique 'classes' that are very distinct.[/list]

[b]CONS:[/b]
[list][*]Some riddles are a little obtuse...
[*]Certain enemies are huge HP sponges.
[*]It uses the Grimrock 'search every wall' secret system.
[*]Slightly limited weapon variety.[/list]

It was actually hard to come up with those cons, because the experience was a very positive one when looking back at it! That alone earns a recommendation, but I'd like to go into detail about some of the above notes. When I say that the [b]difficulty is fine, with hiccups[/b], I mean that in both combat and riddle-mancy! There's a block pushing puzzle in one of the first areas that totally blew my brain out; the solution wound up rather simple but it might have been better a little higher up in the levels. Similarly, there are a few enemies you fight at certain points that are very overwhelming and could probably use a difficulty pass. As I understand it, there's going to be one of those two days after I write this (in a patch), so maybe this will become moot!

As for the [b]price-to-playtime ratio being good,[/b] the value only increases if you're the kind of person who likes to hunt for secrets diligently and/or do multiple playthroughs. There's an achievement to speedrun the game in 90 minutes, but I think even repeated playthroughs would still take 6 - 8 hours when you know where you're going and what to do (if you're taking your time). As for [b]the replayability[/b], there are [b]three unique 'classes'[/b] that are chosen by something called a Rig at the beginning of the game.

One of them is Gadget-oriented, a bit like a mage, and you will pick up two Gadgets rather early on in the game to start you off. They do things like shoot lightning, launch fire forward, spit out poison, etcetera - more or less like spells, and they even use a mana-type system called Energy. At the time of writing, regenerating it can be a hassle and that makes Gadget-type playthroughs a little annoying... But that, again, is apparently going to be addressed in the upcoming patch.

The other two are combat- and then tank-oriented, with the combat-oriented Rig being my favorite. It causes every third attack to deal bonus damage, which makes it the cut-and-dry best in my opinion, but your mileage may vary. The tanking Rig causes you to reflect damage a percentage of the time and even ignore some of it while at low HP, but I didn't spend a lot of time at low HP, so... Not that great for my playstyle. Speaking of playstyles, they do throw in a few tricks that make the typical square-dance maneuver from Grimrock 1 (and some enemies in 2) difficult. I liked that!

That means you're sometimes left with whatever you can see with your eyes, and in one or two cases there didn't appear to be anything to see at all... I just had to bash my head against the wall until something worked. It still didn't detract from the experience a whole lot, though.

[b]Some enemies are HP sponges,[/b] as mentioned above, which means they take a lot of hits before they go down and can be sort of annoying because of that. It does make you have to target-pick in large ambushes, as obviously you're not going to attack the giant sponge first and get yourself cornered. That part's fine, but they could do with a slight nerf (or your damage with a slight buff) in my opinion. There was only one enemy that felt like it had way too much HP, and that was a boss, so it's whatever.

The fact that it [b]uses Grimrock's search-every-wall secret system[/b] might actually be a Pro for some people, but it's not for me. I don't really like crawling through an area I've already completed checking every wall for the secrets I've missed, so I... Didn't! I finished the game with about half of them found, and they were (to the developers' credit) mostly NOT those types of secrets. There are some that are more reliant on observational awareness. Things like, "Hey, that background pipe has a valve on it-- So does that one. I should turn these!" I liked those a lot.

Finally, there's [b]a bit of a limited weapon variety[/b]. That's fine and dandy, to be honest, and there's still plenty to work with, but yeah. They also continue to scale up with each floor, and are one of the most unfair enemies in the game. You wont find yourself bored with combat overall.

Puzzles. This is a dungeon crawler. Expect standard dungeon crawler puzzles. Block pushing puzzles, button pushing puzzles, movement based puzzles, they are all present. I spoke with the devs about it on the fourms, but they pulled off a section of the game that changes the rules entirely and really makes the player react to situations entirely differently. There is a lot of variety to how you can build your character, and while the upgrades in equipment are largely linear, the weapons do have different strengths and the games upgrade system causes the player to focus on a couple of skill paths. The variety in weapon types, as well as the options for sword & board, or dual wield, or two handing, or focusing entirely on "gadgets" there is enough variety here to warrant multiple playthroughs because the combat forces you to play differently simply based on what your build is. I do feel like a couple of skills are GROSSLY overpowered (armorer final skill im looking at you), the upgrades do give the player something to look forward to as opposed to just straight damage or armor uprades.

Overall, Vaporum does a fantastic job of adding a new entry into the dungeon crawling genre that sadly doesnt get enough entries these days. I might not be entirely correct, but i believe their team consisted of 4 people and they did an amazing job. I highly recommend that players who enjoy dungeon crawlers give this game a go. It doesnt change the playing field in massive ways, but it does add another strong entry into the genre, and it is priced fantastically for the content provided in the game.

I say this is a solid 8/10 and once some of the balance issues are fixed, this could easily be an 8.5 with potential for a 9 if they decide to add in any extra areas or expand on the weapons in the game (two hand swords please?)

[b] Holy cow is this game atmospheric! [/b]

Top-notch visuals! Runs great in 4k (I had to enable hardware cursor, otherwise there was a tiny delay in mouse movement recognition.

[h1] Audio [/h1]

Fantastic audio! Clanking gears, rushing water pipes, the tapping of mechanical legs against the floor, coming to hunt you down!

[h1] Story [/h1]

Story is sort of vague and generic, at least in the beginning. But a few minutes in, you start uncovering notes and audio logs, so you will be learning about the crew as you play.

[h1] Combat [/h1]

Combat is real-time, with attacks having different cooldown periods. Even your basic swing of a knife or crowbar has a 1 or so second cooldown, meaning you can't spam click attack. Distance is measured in tiles. 1 tile for melee, and 3 or 4 for various ranged weapons. 

Even though it is real-time, it's sort of "simulated real time". If you sit there and just keep clicking to attack while standing still, you and the enemy will pretty much be trading hits back and forth at a 1:1 ratio...(maybe not exactly 1:1, because different enemies do appear to have different attack speed, but so far from what I've seen, it's pretty close.)

Which leads me to my next point....

[h1] Timing / Movement / Map Awareness [/h1]

Movement! And well, map (or room) awareness. (Note: I have not played with the automap yet, so I can't speak for it, at least not yet.)

Attack Timing / Movement / Room awareness play a HUGE role in combat. Know your tiles, your enemy types/weapon types, and you will be much more successful.

For instance: The first type of enemy you come across is this flying mechanical thing that lunges to hit you. But it sort of "rears back" before lunging. Let it come to you. As soon as it gets within 1 tile, swing your melee weapon to hit it, then instantly back up 1 tile, and the thing will lunge at you and miss, then immediately step forward 1 tile again. Repeat this process with the right timing, and you will avoid 100% damage. At least from that enemy type.

Now, this enemy is easy once you get the hang of it. Different enemies move/attack faster, or maybe at range, or AoE, etc. Each new enemy will bring a new method of combat, and each have their own "best way" to take them down. The fast little spider things are best kited around in a square-like pattern. You can avoid damage from them, but it's a little more difficult to master than the flying thing.

Bottom line - I can't stress Attack timing / Movement / Map Awareness enough. Because you don't get repair kits that often, and you don't want to put yourself in a bad situation when you can't progress!

[h1] RPG Elements [/h1]

Perhaps not as complex as, say, Path of Exile. However, each skill tree does offer some useful-looking abilities. So, you could go Sword and Board, Guns, Dual-Wielding, Tech, and a few others I can't remember right now. 

You have inventory, stats, gear, levels and abilities you learn along the way. You definitely want to explore as much as possible because there are "hidden areas" in the game which usually contain some really good stuff. Break all the barrells, push all the buttons, move all the giant crates!

[b] DO ALL THE THINGS! [/b]

[h1] Summary [/h1]

Great game to sit down with at night, turn up the sound (or wear headphones), and really get lost in! So far, I haven't encountered any bugs!

35523429.review:
Awesome game!

This game builds of the roots of Legend of Grimrock. In that game, there was this weird combat loop where you could squaredance around an enemy to attack them without taking damage. Of course, this was a core part of the gameplay loop but it wasn't really expanded on and it was sort of an accidental result of the realtime gid-based movement, which didn't really serve the game.

On the other hand, Vaporum is designed around this mechanic. Different enemies have different kinds of attack patterns. For instance, one of the enemy types will summon a 9-tile damage attack on a cooldown of a couple seconds. When fighting this enemy, you have to be constantly thinking ahead a couple seconds ahead, making sure that when the next attack happens you have a safe tile to move to. Other enemy types have firearms and can instantaneously damage you from afar. When fihgting these enemies you have to keep track of where everybody is and maneuver yourself to avoid being in the line of sight of any of them. Other enemies hurl projectiles and create temporary damage floors, and there are also immobile turrets which can turn to face four directions and will fire after a short delay once you pass in front of them. On the one hand you have to make sure that when you cross this turret's path, you aren't blocked in from the other side, but you can also exploit this enemy to damage other enemies. All these combinations of enemies, fought in various types of combat spaces, make every encounter unique. It becomes a very strategic game, where you're in big trouble if you maneuver yourself wrong.

You yourself also have a few kinds of "spells" which have different damage patterns, like ranged atttacks, a fire attack which hits two tiles in the direction you're facing (inflictinga debuff which causes damage over time to themselves and any adjacent enemies), and different types of 9-tile AOE attacks (one does instant damage plus inflicting a damage over time debuff that also halves their damage, which is good for minimizing damage when you get surrounded, while another spell doesn't do direct damage but creates an acid floor in a 9-tile area, which continually damages your enemies, which can do more damage but only if your enemies stay in the acid for the whole duration). You can maximize your damage potential by using these attacks smartly, hitting as many enemies as possible while avoiding getting surrounded at the same time.

There are a few different builds you can try, changing your playstyle. The RPG side of things is pretty simplified, the focus of this game is really execution. It is a very skill-based game. It is also very difficult, putting you into many situations much tougher than what you get in Grimrock. Also, oftentimes an encounter will kick your ass multiple times until you realize there is a smarter way to approach the situation, for example, not aggroing every enemy at once, or using a set of double-doors to lure one enemy away from the others first, or using a turret to help damage your enemies. Oftentimes you could not have known the best way to approach an encounter the first time through. There are many encounters that are brutal if you were not already aware of the layout of the area and where the enemies come from. That's why I think this is a game where you should definitely save often. The game is hard enough where the encounters seem to be balanced around a player that already knows how the encounter plays out. Some of the fun is in figuring out how a particular encounter works, and conquering it after a few tries.

The game has no checkpoints, although it auto-saves at the beginning of each floor. There is an option, and corresponding achievement, which disables saving so you can only restart from the beginning of the level.

The graphics are quite good, although some walls look not so good. You can tell this was made by a small team, from things like how items don't have any models when placed on the ground (anything placed on the ground will appear as a sack containing your item, unlike in Grimrock where every item has a unique model). Some of the assets don't look great. But the lighting is nice, and mechanical enemies break apart into pieces when you destroy them which is pretty satisfying. The aesthetic is pretty good, I like the big clunky humanoids, it's just like bioshock again.

I'm still making my way through this game, so I will probably update this review as I go on. But so far I'm really enjoying it.

What can I say? It's an oldschool dungeon crawler in a steam-punk setting with the usual puzzles and hidden secrets.

This one however adds its own twist by using only one character instead of the more common 4 man party often seen in this genre. Personally I don't think this takes anything away from the gameplay itself as many different playstyles still are available, they just took away the crappy ones for the most part.

The combat itself feel a bit more strategic compared to the Grimrock titles with enemies that are faster, uses more AoE attacks and generaly have more different ways of dealing with the player from the usual "hit or shoot anything in front of it". Some enemies side step, others will knock you back, some lunges at you from afar or spit poision and others will blast the area around them, some might even grapple you.

To level the playing field you yourself will gain access to various gadgets and weapons that mimic many of the enemies attacks along with the skills unlocked as you level up. Just keep in mind that enemies that deal a certain type of damage is often immune to it themselves, so hitting a poison spitting enemy with a poison attack wont do anything.
There are also no real weknesses to certain damage types other than blunt weapons doing a bit more damage to mechanical units and bladed weapons doing a bit more to fleshy organic enemies.

As for map design, the visual aspect is really good. The place is dark and full of cogs and pipes like what you'd expect from a spooky steam-punk place and the lightning is beautiful. May wish the flashlight was a tiny bit better however. The layout itself doesn't do much make it feel like a huge tower or research base where people lived and worked. It's a lot more like a typical dungeon full of traps and puzzles. Speaking of, the puzzles are pretty good and I personally never found one that didn't make sense or felt that it suffered from "moon logic" in any way. Solid stuff there.

[h1] TL:DR Morris Dancing with a few new steps. We now need a different dance [/h1]

There were a few moments where I decided this game was good:

1. Stepping in between two deadly turrets expecting certain death and then suddenly realising if I quickly stepped back they might fire on each other. They did.

2. Running away like a pathetic coward from four deadly soldiers and then a thought appeared into my tiny brain. There was a room spitting fireballs not too far away. Maybe I could lure them there?

3. The time a treasure trove was beyond my reach due to a pit of certain death and then I thought, maybe, just maybe, I could move a large block into its deadly jaws and easily cross?

The game makes me secretly pleased about my own intelligence. 

[b] But before we go anywhere else, let’s talk about Dungeon Master and Morris Dancing. [/b]

There are only two games in my personal gaming history that made me want to upgrade my computer. One was Dungeon Master and the other Ultima Underworld.

Dungeon Master was magical, captivating, scary and wondrous. Grid based exploration with real time combat. Let’s see:

*Had to eat food and monster flesh to survive;
*Had to drink water as well;
*Unique magic system using symbols;
*Full steam into walls caused damage to your thick head;
*You could fall down floors of the dungeon and hurt yourself;
*Keys and locks and doors;
*Hidden switches;
*Torches ran out and when darkness came you were blind;
*Luring monsters into doorways and killing them by shutting the door on their stupid heads;
*Running around in panic;
*A party of four adventurers to manage where only [i] using [/i] a skill allowed you to improve.

It spawned other games like Eye of the Beholder and Lands of Lore.

Then like the name ‘Reginald’ it disappeared from our world until Legends of Grimrock brought some life back into the genre.

[b] Does Vaporum bring anything new to the genre? [/b]

[h1] Let’s talk about Morris Dancing first. [/h1]

1. Take two steps to your right, turn around and whack with all your might. 
2. Side step left and 180 degrees then whack the troll, killing is just a breeze!

[b] Combat [/b] in these games is typically known as square dancing where on a 2x2 space you could typically kill any creature just by moving a step and then waiting for it to follow you. It’s sort of lame but staple of the genre.

Vaporum tries to innovate here and I acknowledge the developers tried to stop this from happening. Now I am beginning to think it is simply a consequence of the genre. In this game there are many instances of having to take on more than one opponent at a time, but still the square dancing arose, sometimes due to my own design.

Combat though is interesting. You can build your character in melee, guns or magic or a mixture of everything, including defence. 

We still encounter the common situation in the genre where stepping through, the door closes behind you and a few monster types attack you from previously closed spaces. One time I saw an enemy elevated through the floor which was neat. 

[b] 3D puzzles [/b] come back with a bang. These range from leaving a little brick on a pressure plate to timing puzzles involving blocking rays of light. At one point two at a time!

Some of these puzzles will make you mad with frustration and lead you to searching the forums and walkthroughs. Personally I liked the Sokoban puzzle.

I don’t remember the puzzles being a staple of the genre in the early days and maybe it was Legend of Grimrock that brought enhanced puzzling into the arena. Now we have timing, throwing, falling, stepping, any of which often stop your progress. Many times I question why these puzzles are there in the world. It’s almost like the player is caught in a rats maze with the developer trying to establish our intelligence. As if the game was an elaborate IQ test disguised as a game. In Vaporum I asked myself why in this world I had to solve THIS puzzle to proceed. It made no sense.

Beyond combat the levels are of different design to keep things fresh but the individual maps are too small. Dungeon Master was a bit sprawling but this game is more compact. I suppose because you are in a building, not a random, meandering underground dungeon. We do have the ability to annotate maps which is a plus but unlike many other games where I would have loved to have had that option, in Vaporum I found myself only using that option once.

[b] Monsters are well designed and at least one causing me to soil myself and another jumping out of my chair. [/b]

I hate the little spider things. There is a wide range of abilities and some have patterns that can disrupt your Morris Dancing. These are good.

Your single character is part voiced which is good innovation for the genre. There is a slight Bioshock meets Dungeon Master feel to the product which is fascinating in what else can be done in the future.  Some of the background story can be read and others heard via recordings.

I liked the levelling system and the options to build your character as it was quite flexible. If you had played as a melee character there is a good possibility you might try another play through using magic.

The graphics and sound are almost stupendous as a representative of the genre. It’s a shame though that I have not found any light switches to see what the engine looks like in full brightness mode. 

In summary then, as someone who has played a lot of games in this genre, I like it a lot. It has certainly brought some innovation to the genre and I am looking forward with some positivity to the future. Ultimately though, this game only adds a few new steps to Morris Dancing and I think it’s time we have a completely new dance.

After recently beating Legend of Grimrock II for the first time, I immediately regained my appetite for another FPRPG dungeon-crawl the very same day Vaporum released. I had never even seen the game listed on Steam anywhere nor had it reccomended, but it looked to be right up my alley, not to mention that it seemed to offer just enough tweaks and changes to set it apart. 

Surprisingly there is a shortage of steampunk/low-tech sci-fi games in general, so the setting and graphic design were welcome, and the graphics in general are polished and original. The aesthetic of gears and pistons and steam is great, with plenty of dynamic shadows and good sound design, though plenty of areas seem way too dark and sometimes the reflective metal surfaces can be a little overbearing.

Rather than having a four-man party as is standard of the genre, you play a single predetermined character, though he doesn't seem very interesting even several hours in. Couple that with some slightly cheesy voice-acting, I would have preferred character creation in a game like this, though the various notes and audio diaries you find develop the story pretty well. The introduction may seem extremely reminiscent of Bioshock, but the story and atmosphere manages to go in a very different direction.

Mechanically, there is plenty of customization and development for your character, with different weapon types and gadgets to use, and the combat is pretty tight and fast-paced. Early on you can generally dance around single enemies to avoid damage, but later rooms and groups of enemies will require quick thinking and good memory of tiles and rooms, as well as knowing which enemies to pick apart and which to knock out later.

Besides combat, there are plenty of traps and puzzles to fiddle around with, usually involving switches, turrets, buttons, trapdoors, and even the occasional block-pushing puzzle. The obstacles never feel annoying or obnoxious, though for some reason there are pits full of spikes that will instantly kill you in this pseudo-modern sci-fi tower, so do remember to manually save often and watch your step.

The introduction of the game is pretty easy, but it quickly gets challenging or outright frustrating. Despite that, if it feels like a level is too hard or unreasonable, you can take different paths in order to find equipment and enemies more suitable for your character. There are also secret rooms with unique equipment or stat upgrades throughout the game, so cooling off from a difficult area and experimenting is beneficial.

At this point I've tried at least three different character builds, so most of my play time has been playing through the first few hours multiple times, but the game has plenty of content and good variety of obstacles and environments, as well as consistently giving you new puzzles with interesting solutions. Developing your characters skills and stats also drastically changes how you can play the game, so there's plenty of potential for replay value.

In terms of content, the only disappointment so far is that the game reuses most of the basic enemies and introduces new enemies very gradually, with all the old ones simply getting higher stats. 

If you're in the mood for a different flavor of first-person RPG, I'd say it's definitely worth the money, though I may suggest playing on Easy even if you've beaten other games like it.

It's a neat combination between tile-based movement and real-time combat (think Legend of Grimrock in Steampunk world). Take it if you enjoyed the combat in legend of grimrock / old might and magic series. If you prefer turn-based experience - proceed at your own risk :)

[h1]Gameplay + Review Vid, if you'd rather watch[/h1]
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CI-UXobuioA

[h1]About The Game[/h1]
Vaporum is a grid-based dungeon crawler RPG in an original steampunk setting. It has this old-school dungeon crawling in first-person perspective. This is something you would encounter when playing the old Might and Magic games or the newer Legend of Grimrock series.
Your hero wakes up on an island in front of a mystic tower without any memory of who he is, what happened here and how he got here. Obviously, he decides to enter. That’s how the game begins.

Now, personally, the first thing I usually think about when I hear “dungeon-crawling” is turn-based, randomly generated level exploration. The game has neither: the levels are pre-defined and the combat happens in real time. The only thing that resembles turn-based gameplay is movement: you don’t get to move freely. Instead, the dungeon is split into tiles and you can move from tile to tile only. This constraint is done pretty seamlessly, so the movement limit won’t bother you.

[h1]The Gameplay[/h1]

As I mentioned, the fights are in real-time: monsters have attack patterns and abilities, which you can remember and use to your advantage. When fighting the simplest ones – you can simply “dance” by moving forward one tile to attack and back one tile when they attack you, avoiding damage this way. The harder ones tend to move less predictably or have ranged attacks – so dodging will require considerably higher game expertise. This is where the game actually shines: you have a classical RPG-like inventory and levelling system, but those stats (depending on your chosen difficulty) are only an addition to your mechanical play skills. On higher difficulties, you can’t simply stand on one place, hit enemies and then use healing items. You’ll simply run out of repair kits and die.

The strong part of the game is immersion: the sounds fit the dark tower atmosphere well. The lightning is just about right: darker tones that allow you to see where are you going, but still make you feel like you are in the tower of evil. The level design supplements that: in this case you see how pre-defined levels have a clear advantage over randomly-generated content. You’ll be getting notes, “diaries,” that drive the plot forward. You’ll be hearing creepy noises while trying to figure out what happened. Levers, switches, keys – those are essential parts of your crawling experience. The puzzles that tower presents you are not complicated, but will still dilute the combat and give you some rest.

The game was marketed as “Legend of Grimrock” in Steampunk universe and it’s pretty much correct. Unfortunately, that also includes the flaws with camera controls. Turning happens by pressing the Q/E keys or holding middle mouse key and then dragging the mouse towards new direction. This is OK for exploration and puzzle solving. But in the midst of battle, this adds another set of buttons that delay your actions. One obvious solution would be to allow turning during the battles without keyholding, but alas, it’s not there.
Summary

[h1]Summary[/h1]
Despite the high production quality, Vaporum definitely won’t be for everyone. Personally I find the mix between tile mechanics and real-time combat a bit awkward, but that should not deter you from the experience. If you enjoyed Legend of Grimrock – you are going to enjoy this game too. And because of the great immersion and skill-based, difficult combat, I highly recommend the game to legend of grimrock fans and those of you who look for more games in steampunk setting.

[b]TL:DR[/b] - If you are looking for another dungeon Crawler of the Dungeon Master Variety, then I can recommend this product without hesitation.  If you are wondering what separates this title from the rest of the options that are on the market now, then you will want to read a little further.

Bottom line, I can definitely recommend this title, as I have enjoyed the 6+ hours I have been entertained by, by the time of this review.  I may have more to add to this review, when I finally complete the game.  This review is entirely based around a 6 hour preview of the game title, and I am not sure how much longer I have to complete the game.


[b]Gameplay: [/b]

This game is a simple one, and this may be a put off for some who really enjoy robust stat/inventory management.  You have the following:
	Three Classes (Combat, Toughness, Tech themed classes)
	One playable character
	No Stat modifications beyond equipment, so there is VERY little character sheet management.

There is not a huge variety of equipment to loot, or many abilities to obtain, or many passive augments to obtain, so all and all you will spend far more time, exploring the dungeon and interacting with puzzles and enemies than you will navigating your inventory and character sheet.  This, ends up working.  It keeps the pacing of the game moving much faster than it would otherwise were you to be forced to micromanage several aspects of your character growth beyond equipping new gear and allocating a skill point obtained each level.

This could be a turnoff for some, and I will admit that I am partial for extreme character customization.  After playing through to floor 6 though, I have found that it has been far more enjoyable to not have to worry so much about my character as I would normally in other games.  It really helps with the pacing and flow of the game to keep things simple.

Inventory management turned out to be a very limited aspect of the game as well.  Gone are pockets of infinite space, and in an almost survival horror esque fashion, I found myself to be lacking resources (like medkits) far more times than I would have prefered, which really forced me to figure out how to properly manipulate the enemies to my advantage as opposed to simply rushing each challenge.  

The game does a great job of scaling difficulty, with lessons learned.  From the start of the game, new concepts are introduced, and from the point a concept is introduced, the game then proceeds to implement your lessons learned in progressively more difficult situations.  There is a real sense of progression through the game as a result.

[b]Playability:[/b]

I started the game in Hard mode, as I wanted to see the scale by which the game challenges the player.  Some games are astronomically difficult for all the wrong reasons, but this game is not one of those cases.  Yes there were some periods of time, where I found myself beyond frustrated over how unfair my situations ended up being, but I had not been presented with a situation (combat or puzzle) where I could not proceed due to the difficulty.

I did however, encounter a floor that I simply have not been able to resolve, so I am not sure if it is unsolvable due to the beta version, or that I simply missing  some aspect of the solution somewhere.

[b]*EDIT* (09/28/2017) - I managed to figure out how to do this part, and it was a pretty devistating puzzle, but mostly due to my lack of observation.  This does re-enforce a common theme through the puzzles, that discovery is the first half, then execution is the second. It did stump me good.[/b]

The easier modes (down to easy at least), make the enemies less devastating, but not less aggressive.  This allows for players of all skill levels to properly engage the game without feeling totally overwhelmed, while still allowing for a standard and potentially challenging experience on all levels of skill.

[b]Sound:[/b]

The ambient atmosphere, and the sound effects are all great.  
Unfortunately, this segment is home to my primary issue I have with the game.
The voice overs.  

The VAs (voice actors) are not inherently bad.  It is much appreciated that they are included as many of the games available now, simply don't have them.

The problem comes from the fact that you have ONE player character, and the game addresses the character as a defined entity in the world.  This means, that by giving that character agency and personality to deliver commentary through the adventure, he is then essential to deliver and drive the plot/story.  This is where the game falls short.  

Several times through the adventure, your character will say comments (*not exact quotes* "Look up there, see that" when calling a hidden item, "That was nasty.", "I hate those things.", ETC.).  

There are audio recordings that deliver backstory in the world that are fully voice acted as well.  

My issue is that through the written notes of the world, and other various mousovers of areas that involve the copious amounts of lore related texts;  I personally would have prefered that the main character voice act all of the spare text as if he is reading the notes, or observing the signs and locations within the game.  He could read one of those notes, and then add an element of commentary that would flesh out the story.   Instead, silence, and you the reader are supposed to read the letters, and interpret them as you see fit.  I just see this as a missed opportunity to deliver a compelling story, since the game is clearly telling the story through his perspective.

[b]Recommendation?:[/b]

I do recommend this.  It was fun, it was challenging, and the puzzles (till the one I got stuck on) were intuitive, and entertaining to solve.  It may not be for everyone, but for those looking for a 6 to 10 hour explorative dungeon crawl, I would expect that you would not be embarrassed to add this title in your game library.

[b]What I would have liked to see?:[/b]

I would have liked to see more context based story delivery from the primary character's voice acting.
I would have liked to see more interactivity with the world.  One of the biggest "same old, same old" factors involved with games of this sub-genre, is how limited the interactivity with the world ends up being.  This game does not break any grounds with how interactive the environments are.  I would have loved to see more of that.  Breakable walls, secret switches, interactive environments, etc. etc.
